abstract.p: Dr Alan H Lockwood letter scores medical waste incinerators for amount of mercury they discharge

block.p: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. (Op-Ed, Sept. 18) points out that Midwestern power plants discharge mercury, as well as the gases that are precursors of acid rain. While the behavior of the utilities might be expected in a free-market economy, there is no excuse for another purveyor of mercury: the health care industry.

Robert F. Kennedy Jr. (Op-Ed, Sept. 18) points out that Midwestern power plants discharge mercury, as well as the gases that are precursors of acid rain. While the behavior of the utilities might be expected in a free-market economy, there is no excuse for another purveyor of mercury: the health care industry.
According to the Environmental Protection Agency, medical waste incinerators discharge almost one-third as much mercury as power plants and, perhaps worse, are the third-ranked source of dioxins.

Yet attempts to tighten regulation of these incinerators were opposed successfully by the powerful Hospital Association of America. ''First do no harm,'' the fundamental tenet of the Hippocratic oath, should reach beyond the doctor's office.
ALAN H. LOCKWOOD, M.D. Buffalo, Sept. 20, 1999
The writer is a professor of neurology and nuclear medicine, State University of New York at Buffalo.
